prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Where possible, copies of documents containing confidential information should be numbered. This will help to ensure that the company knows where confidential documents are located. As individuals leave or copies are destroyed, a master list can be updated.

When confidential information is no longer needed, it should be properly destroyed. Documents should not simply be thrown out or recycled. Stories of documents being taken from the garbage by third parties offer sufficient warning of the need to conduct this process in a thorough manner. In some extreme cases, companies have even lost confidential information after third parties put together documents that had been shredded. In Pinto v. Mancinelli,[1] Master Sproat found that where there was an allegation of misuse of personal information by third party experts and the experts claimed witness immunity, the issue of witness immunity should be determined at trial on the basis of a complete factual record.
